name: 2,6-dichlorobenzaldehyde
Reason: 2,6-dichlorobenzaldehyde has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The presence of two chlorine atoms increases the molecular weight and electronegativity, which raises the melting point by approximately +20 °C. The aldehyde group introduces a carbonyl functional group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and rigidify the structure, estimated at around +10 °C. The additional functional groups and structural features in 2,6-dichlorobenzaldehyde will affect its melting point: (1) The two chlorine atoms increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and electronegativity. (2) The aldehyde group introduces a carbonyl functional group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and rigidify the structure.
